title: Captain Seafarer's Clam Chowder
story: The fog hung thick as molasses over Nantucket harbor on that fateful winter morning in 1879. Captain Josiah Seafarer, weathered by forty years of navigating treacherous waters, stood at the helm of his fishing vessel, the Salty Maiden. His crew—exhausted, cold, and disheartened after a week of empty nets—muttered about turning back. The captain, however, felt a strange tingling in his sea-weathered bones, a sixth sense that had saved his hide more times than he could count on his remaining fingers. 'Just beyond this veil of fog,' he proclaimed, his voice carrying over the lapping waves, 'lies our fortune.' Hours later, as if by divine providence, they stumbled upon an undiscovered cove teeming with the largest, meatiest clams any of them had ever beheld. The local indigenous tribe, who had kept this cove secret for generations, appeared on the shore. Rather than chase the sailors away, their elder approached Captain Seafarer, having recognized in him a kindred spirit who respected the sea's gifts. He shared with the captain an ancient recipe—a creamy concoction that warmed the soul and fortified the body against the harshest elements. That night, as a nor'easter howled outside their cabin, the crew feasted on what would become legendary as Captain Seafarer's Clam Chowder. The captain recorded the recipe in his logbook, noting that the simple meal had prevented a mutiny and possibly saved all their lives. For years afterward, whenever the Salty Maiden returned to port after a successful voyage, the captain would invite the entire town to share in a massive cauldron of his famous chowder. Maritime historians now credit this tradition with cementing the bonds that allowed Nantucket to survive several economic downturns. The chowder, thick enough to stand a spoon in, seemed to capture the very essence of the sea itself, each spoonful containing mysteries and comforts that spoke of distant shores and the universal language of hospitality that unites all seafaring folk.
ingredients: 1 pound russet potatoes, peeled and diced into 1/2-inch cubes
1 pound fresh clams, cleaned and chopped (or 3 cans of chopped clams, drained with juice reserved)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste
instructions: In a large heavy-bottomed pot or Dutch oven, cook the diced bacon over medium heat until crisp, about 5-6 minutes.
Remove the bacon with a slotted spoon and set aside, leaving the drippings in the pot.
Add the diced onion and celery to the bacon drippings and cook until softened, about 5 minutes.
Sprinkle the flour over the vegetables and stir continuously for 1-2 minutes to create a roux.
Gradually whisk in the clam juice, ensuring there are no lumps.
Add the milk, cream, diced potatoes, bay leaves, and thyme. Bring to a simmer.
Reduce heat to low and cook, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are tender, about 15-20 minutes.
Add the chopped clams and reserved crispy bacon bits to the pot. If using canned clams, add any reserved clam juice as well.
Simmer for an additional 5 minutes until the clams are cooked through (if using fresh) or heated through (if using canned).
Stir in the butter and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Remove the bay leaves before serving.
Ladle into bowls, garnish with fresh parsley, and serve with oyster crackers on the side.
